On Monday, March 16, 2020, through Friday, March 20, 2020, Forsyth County Schools will be offering free meal pick-up service for all students on the campuses of Sawnee ES and Whitlow ES from 12 – 1 pm. This is open to all public and private school students in Forsyth County, pre-school to age 18 (21 for special needs students).
Students MUST BE present with the adult during pick-up. We will be providing two free meals – one lunch for the day, one breakfast for the following day – via a drive-thru service.
Sawnee ES: 1616 Canton Highway, Cumming, GA 30040
Whitlow ES: 3655 Castleberry Road, Cumming, GA 30040
If you would like to assist others in our community in regards to COVID-19, please make food donations to The Place of Forsyth County and financial donations to United Way of Forsyth County at www.unitedwayforsyth.com/donatenow. A needs list, which also includes an Amazon ordering option, and drop-off address are posted at https://www.theplaceofforsyth.org/

FTE Campaign, Day 2
"Who Do You Love?"

From Jeff Thompson, Mentor Services Director: "Mentors meet with their mentees in group once a month. We combine these group meetings we have been having with the new monthly FTE night and any other events that might be taking place any given month. Tonight we began with the Title I meeting, offering to give parents a tour of the building and also giving them the opportunity to meet their child's mentor if they hadn't yet. While that was happening, we offered the kids hot chocolate and doughnuts, and as they sat at tables with their mentors, they were given mardi gras beads, drew lots for a box of chocolates and talked about what they loved, the theme of the night, in honor of Valentine's Day. The mentors asked what each student loved... something concrete and something abstract. The turnout was great, and lots of kids won in the general drawing that preceded the snack-fest."

Steve Gooch is the majority whip in the Georgia Senate and represents Lumpkin, Dawson and parts of Forsyth Counties. His areas of expertise include education, transportation and infrastructure. In addition, he is currently involved in a wage survey to provide law enforcement with a competitive wage while also spearheading the effort to improve broadband internet performance, particularly in the rural areas. Senator Gooch, as he has for the past several years, was our host for the 2018 version of "A Day at the Capitol."

A compilation of teacher comments describes the recipient: "Justin has great attendance. He is always positive and smiling. Justin has worked diligently to improve his writing. He shows up each week and does his work with a smile on his face. He is a joy to teach." Chaniqua Ewing (left), school social worker, and Jeff Thompson, director of mentor services are also pictured.
